content: The Act may be cited as the "Welfare Reform and Responsibility Act of 1993" and requires work in exchange for aid to families with dependent children. The Welfare Reform and Responsibility Act of 1993 mandates states to include community work experience programs in the JOBS program and enroll AFDC recipients not participating in JOBS in a CWEP. The Welfare Reform and Responsibility Act of 1993 mandates states to include community work experience programs in the JOBS program for AFDC recipients. SEC. 3. FRAUD REDUCTION. States are required to operate a toll-free telephone number for reporting fraud or abuse in the program. The number must be available 24 hours a day and publicized to callers. The Office of Investigations in the Department of Health and Human Services is authorized to receive up to $60,000,000 for fiscal year 1994. SEC. 4. ASSESSMENTS OF NEEDS AND SKILLS; EMPLOYABILITY PLANS. Section 402(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include new provisions regarding aid recipients' employability plans. These plans must aim to transition recipients from aid to work within 2 years, with specific goals and timetables set. Section 402(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include new provisions requiring aid recipients to set specific goals and timetables for transitioning from aid to work within 2 years, with plans reviewed and updated every 6 months. ELIGIBILITY REVIEW. Section 402(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to provide for the establishment of panels composed of 3 former State judges to review recipients of aid under the plan who have received aid for 2 consecutive years and determine their participation in the program and efforts to become employed. The Social Security Act is amended to establish panels of former State judges to review aid recipients who have received aid for 2 consecutive years, determine their participation in the program, and address disputes using established procedures. SEC. 6. FAMILY PROVISIONS. States must offer parenting courses to all teenage parents not in school, covering topics like family planning, health, nutrition, and child development. Additionally, states must provide incentives for using certain contraceptive methods. States must establish a program that provides incentives for recipients of aid to use implanted, temporary, hormonal contraceptive devices. Each state is entitled to payments from the Secretary for implementing this program. The State is entitled to payments from the Secretary equal to the Federal medical assistance percentage of the expenditures in operating the required program. SEC. 7 amends the Social Security Act to expand job training and educational opportunities by increasing federal payments to states for program expenditures exceeding 60 percent of fiscal year 1992 levels. SEC. 8 focuses on work incentives and reducing barriers to employment. The Social Security Act is amended to encourage employment by changing the Earned Income Disregard. This includes amendments to sections 402(a)(8)(B)(ii) and 402(a)(37) of the Act. Section 402(g)(1)(A)(ii) of the Social Security Act is amended to replace "subsection (a)(8)(B)(ii)(II)" with "the inapplicability of subsection (a)(8)(A)(iv)". Section 482(e)(2)(G)(ii) is also amended to replace "the provisions of subparagraph (A)(iv)" with "section 402(a)(8)(A)(iv) without regard to the time limitation". Additionally, Section 1925(a)(1) is amended to replace "section 402(a)(8)(B)(ii)(II)" with "the inapplicability of section 402(a)(8)(A)(iv)". Optional State Extension of Medicaid Enrollment for Former AFDC Recipients allows states to offer families the option to extend coverage for up to 4 succeeding 6-month periods under the same conditions. The amendment also changes the heading of the section from "Requirement" to "In general". The amendment allows states to offer Medicaid coverage extensions for former AFDC recipients for up to 5 additional periods, with premiums based on a sliding scale tied to family income.
